data.title: New movies in Memphis and special screenings, Feb. 23-March 1, 2018
data.meta_description: Here are the movies opening in the Memphis area this week, plus special screenings, Feb. 23-March 1, 2018
data.text:
Here are the movies opening in the Memphis area this week, plus special screenings, Feb. 23-March 1.

Opening Friday

Annihilation (R, 115 min.) Natalie Portman, Oscar Isaac and Jennifer Jason Leigh explore an environmental disaster zone in a new science-fiction film from director Alex Garland ("Ex Machina"), based on a novel by Jeff VanderMeer.

CinePlanet 16, Collierville Towne 16, Cordova, DeSoto 16, Olive Branch, Paradiso.

Every Day (PG-13, 95 min.) A 16-year-old girl (Angourie Rice) falls in love with a mysterious soul who inhabits a new body every day.

CinePlanet 16, Collierville Towne 16, Cordova, DeSoto 16, Forest Hill, Hollywood 20, Olive Branch, Paradiso, Stage.

Game Night (R, 100 min.) A group of friends (Rachel McAdams, Jason Bateman, Jesse Plemons) who meet for a regular "game night" become embroiled in a comedy murder mystery.

CinePlanet 16, Collierville Towne 16, Cordova, DeSoto 16, Forest Hill, Hollywood 20, Majestic, Olive Branch, Palace, Paradiso, Stage, Studio on the Square, Summer Quartet Drive-In, Wolfchase Galleria 8.

Gujjubhai: Most Wanted (Not rated, 157 min.) A Gujarati-language comedy from India.

Hollywood 20.

The Lodgers (R, 92 min.) Twins are haunted by a sinister presence in this Gothic horror film set in 1920s rural Ireland.

Majestic.

Naachiyaar (Not rated, 100 min.) A Tamil-language police drama.

Majestic.

Special Screenings

The Black Hole (G, 127 min.) From 1979, Disney's spaciest (in more ways than one) live-action movie follows Anthony Perkins, Yvette Mimieux, Ernest Borgnine and a cute R2-D2 wannabe named V.I.N.CENT on an interstellar journey to the edge of a collapsed star.

4 p.m. Saturday and Sunday, CTI 3D Giant Theater, Memphis Pink Palace Museum, 3050 Central Ave. Call 901-636-2362 or visit memphismuseums.org for tickets and reservations.

The Dark Crystal (PG, 93 min.) A new introduction by daughter Lisa Henson precedes this big-screen revival of Jim Henson's 1982 live-action puppet fantasy in which elfin "Gelflings" challenge the evil "Skeksis" for control of the magical world of Thra.

2 p.m. Sunday and 7 p.m. Wednesday, Paradiso. Tickets: $13.50. Visit malco.com.

Dream Big: Engineering Our World 3D (Not rated, 42 min.) Jeff Bridges narrates this spectacular look at some of the Earth's largest or most ambitious building projects, from China's ancient Great Wall to the robots and solar cars of today.

Through Nov. 16, CTI 3D Giant Theater, Memphis Pink Palace Museum, 3050 Central Ave. Call 901-636-2362 or visit memphismuseums.org for showtimes, tickets and reservations.

Extreme Weather 3D (Not rated, 45 min.) With dynamic footage of thunderstorms, twisters, wildfires and other weather-related events, this National Geographic movie examines the much discussed but little understood forces that shape our planet.

CTI 3D Giant Theater, Memphis Pink Palace Museum, 3050 Central Ave. Call 901-636-2362 or visit memphismuseums.org for showtimes, tickets and reservations.

Kirk Cameron: Connect (Not rated, 70 min.) The sitcom star turned evangelical Christian hosts a documentary that offers advice to parents seeking to protect their children from the dangers of the social-media environment.

7 p.m. Tuesday and Thursday, Paradiso. Tickets: $13.50. Visit malco.com.

The Metropolitan Opera: La Bohème (Not rated, 200 min.) Filmed live onstage in New York, a new production of Puccini's masterpiece.

11:30 a.m. Saturday and 6:30 p.m. Wednesday, Paradiso. Tickets: $21. Visit malco.com.

MLK50 Hometowner Shorts (Not rated, 87 min.) Themes of race and social justice are explored in this program of 11 short films by local artists, including "Arkabutla," the debut film by award-winning playwright Katori Hall.

7 p.m. Wednesday, National Civil Rights Museum. Admission: free. Visit indiememphis.com.

Monsieur Mayonnaise (Not rated, 95 min.) The International Jewish Film Festival concludes with a documentary in which Australian director Philippe Mora ("Howling II") explores his "secret past" and discovers (according to the Internet Movie Database) "artists, werewolves, heroes, Nazis, a comic book and baguettes...with lashings of French mayonnaise!"

7:30 p.m. Tuesday, Ridgeway Cinema Grill. Tickets: $7, or $5 for Memphis Jewish Community Center members. Visit jccmemphis.org.

National Theatre Live: Cat on a Hot Tin Roof (Not rated, 185 mon.) Jack O'Connell is "Brick," Colm Meany is plantation patriarch "Big Daddy" and Sienna Miller is sultry "Maggie the Cat" in this filmed-live-onstage-in-London revival of Tennessee Williams' steamy Mississippi-set masterpiece.

1 p.m. Sunday and 7 p.m. Tuesday, Paradiso. Tickets: $20. Visit malco.com.

New Initial D the Movie Double Feature (Not rated, 127 min.) Based on a manga series about street racing, the Japanese animated films "New Initial D the Movie: Legend 1 — Awakening" and "New Initial D the Movie: Legend 2 — Racer" are screened back to back.

7 p.m. Monday and Wednesday, Paradiso. Tickets: $15. Visit malco.com.

Oscar-Nominated Shorts — Animation (Not rated, 83 min.) Representing a wide range of styles, from traditional hand-drawn cartooning to stop-motion and computer animation, the five Academy Award nominees in the category of Best Animated Short Film receive a theatrical screening, joined by an additional three cartoons.

6 p.m. Sunday, Studio on the Square. Tickets: $10. Visit onlocationmemphis.org.

Oscar-Nominated Shorts — Documentary (Not rated, 179 min.) The five Academy Award nominees in the category of Documentary Short Subject receive a theatrical screening. The topics include health care, racial profiling, the opioid epidemic and more.

3 p.m. Sunday, Studio on the Square. Tickets: $10. Visit onlocationmemphis.org.

Oscar-Nominated Shorts — Live Action (Not rated, 96 min.) Kenya, Australia, the United Kingdom and the U.S. will be represented in this screening of the five Academy Award nominees in the category of Best Live Action Short Film.

6 p.m. Monday, Studio on the Square. Tickets: $10. Visit onlocationmemphis.org.

Piano Man Pictures Roadshow (Not rated, 100 min.) An anthology of four dark and weird short films from the local Piano Man Pictures production company, including Shelby Baldock's "Faceless, But Remembered," Chad Allen Barton's "H.I.D.," Rachel M. Taylor's special effects-filled "Avarice," and Stephen Teague's "The Price of Air." The four directors will attend, to introduce their films and answer questions after the screening.

7 p.m. Friday, the Hi-Tone, 412 N. Cleveland. Tickets: $10. Visit pianomanpictures.com.

Primal Rage — Bigfoot Reborn (R, 106 min.) Special makeup effects artist-turned-director Patrick Magee helms this new horror movie in which a young couple (Casey Gagliardi and Andrew Joseph Montgomery) encounter a monstrous ancient creature after they become lost in the woods of the Pacific Northwest.

7 p.m. Tuesday, Cordova. Tickets: $13.50. Visit malco.com.

Wild Africa 3D (Not rated, 45 min.) Explore the deserts, coral reefs, snow-covered mountains, great rivers, steamy rain forests and wide-open savannahs of an incredibly diverse continent.

CTI 3D Giant Theater, Memphis Pink Palace Museum, 3050 Central Ave. Call 901-636-2362 or visit memphismuseums.org for showtimes, tickets and reservations.
